1→# Patterns & Conventions
     2→
     3→Solutions to problems you will encounter building Safo. Read before implementing.
     4→
     5→---
     6→
     7→## 0. MarkdownUI Custom Theme
     8→
     9→**Problem:** MarkdownUI ships with default themes but Safo needs fully custom typography,
    10→colors, and spacing for every markdown element.
    11→
    12→**Solution:** Create a custom `Theme` conforming to MarkdownUI's `Theme` protocol. Override
    13→every block and inline style.
    14→
    15→```swift
    16→import MarkdownUI
    17→
    18→struct SafoTheme: Theme {
    19→    // Use MarkdownUI's theme API to customize:
    20→    // - text styles (body, code, headings)
    21→    // - block styles (paragraph, blockquote, code block, table, list)
    22→    // - inline styles (strong, emphasis, strikethrough, code, link)
    23→    //
    24→    // Reference: https://github.com/gonzalezreal/swift-markdown-ui
    25→    // Look at Theme+DocC.swift and Theme+GitHub.swift in the repo for examples.
    26→}
    27→```
    28→
    29→**Gotcha:** MarkdownUI 2.x uses a declarative theme system with `BlockStyle` and
    30→`InlineStyle`. Do not try to use AttributedString directly. Work with the theme API.
    31→
    32→**Gotcha:** For heading sizes, MarkdownUI gives you the heading level (1-6) in the
    33→`BlockConfiguration`. Use a switch to apply different sizes per level.
    34→
    35→---
    36→
    37→## 1. Splash Integration with MarkdownUI
    38→
    39→**Problem:** MarkdownUI needs a code syntax highlighter. Splash is Swift-native but needs
    40→to be wired into MarkdownUI's code block rendering.
    41→
    42→**Solution:** MarkdownUI 2.x supports custom code syntax highlighters via the
    43→`.markdownCodeSyntaxHighlighter` modifier. Create a Splash-based highlighter.
    44→
    45→```swift
    46→import MarkdownUI
    47→import Splash
    48→
    49→struct SplashCodeHighlighter: CodeSyntaxHighlighter {
    50→    let theme: Splash.Theme
    51→
    52→    func highlightCode(_ code: String, language: String?) -> Text {
    53→        guard let language = language else {
    54→            return Text(code)
    55→        }
    56→        // Use Splash's SyntaxHighlighter to produce highlighted output
    57→        // Convert Splash's attributed output to SwiftUI Text
    58→    }
    59→}
    60→```
    61→
    62→**Gotcha:** Splash only highlights Swift natively. For other languages, it provides basic
    63→keyword highlighting. This is acceptable for v1. For more languages, consider switching to
    64→a different highlighter later.
    65→
    66→**Gotcha:** If Splash doesn't recognize the language, fall back to plain monospace text.
    67→Never crash on unknown languages.
    68→
    69→---
    70→
    71→## 2. Window Positioning on Launch
    72→
    73→**Problem:** Safo needs to open at 40% screen width, full height, positioned on the right
    74→side of the screen.
    75→
    76→**Solution:** Use `NSApplicationDelegate` to position the window after it appears.
    77→
    78→```swift
    79→class AppDelegate: NSObject, NSApplicationDelegate {
    80→    func applicationDidFinishLaunching(_ notification: Notification) {
    81→        positionWindow()
    82→    }
    83→
    84→    private func positionWindow() {
    85→        guard let screen = NSScreen.main else { return }
    86→        guard let window = NSApplication.shared.windows.first else { return }
    87→
    88→        let screenFrame = screen.visibleFrame
    89→        let width = screenFrame.width * Tokens.Layout.windowWidthRatio
    90→        let frame = NSRect(
    91→            x: screenFrame.maxX - width,
    92→            y: screenFrame.minY,
    93→            width: width,
    94→            height: screenFrame.height
    95→        )
    96→        window.setFrame(frame, display: true, animate: false)
    97→    }
    98→}
    99→```
   100→
   101→**Gotcha:** Use `screen.visibleFrame` not `screen.frame`. The visible frame excludes the
   102→menu bar and dock.
   103→
   104→**Gotcha:** The window may not exist yet when `applicationDidFinishLaunching` fires. Use
   105→`DispatchQueue.main.async` if needed, or observe `NSWindow.didBecomeKeyNotification`.
   106→
   107→---
   108→
   109→## 3. File Watching with DispatchSource
   110→
   111→**Problem:** Safo must detect when the currently viewed file changes on disk and reload.
   112→
   113→**Solution:** Use `DispatchSource.makeFileSystemObjectSource` to watch a specific file.
   114→
   115→```swift
   116→class FileWatcher {
   117→    private var source: DispatchSourceFileSystemObject?
   118→    private var fileDescriptor: Int32 = -1
   119→
   120→    init(url: URL, onChange: @escaping () -> Void) {
   121→        fileDescriptor = open(url.path, O_EVTONLY)
   122→        guard fileDescriptor >= 0 else { return }
   123→
   124→        source = DispatchSource.makeFileSystemObjectSource(
   125→            fileDescriptor: fileDescriptor,
   126→            eventMask: [.write, .rename, .delete],
   127→            queue: .main
   128→        )
   129→
   130→        source?.setEventHandler { [weak self] in
   131→            onChange()
   132→        }
   133→
   134→        source?.setCancelHandler { [weak self] in
   135→            guard let fd = self?.fileDescriptor, fd >= 0 else { return }
   136→            close(fd)
   137→        }
   138→
   139→        source?.resume()
   140→    }
   141→
   142→    deinit {
   143→        source?.cancel()
   144→    }
   145→}
   146→```
   147→
   148→**Gotcha:** Always close the file descriptor in the cancel handler, not in deinit directly.
   149→The cancel handler runs asynchronously.
   150→
   151→**Gotcha:** Some editors (like vim) write by creating a new file and renaming. This triggers
   152→`.rename` or `.delete` on the original descriptor. When you detect rename/delete, re-create
   153→the watcher for the same path.
   154→
   155→**Gotcha:** Debounce the onChange callback (100ms). Editors may write multiple times rapidly.
   156→
   157→---
   158→
   159→## 4. URL Scheme Handling
   160→
   161→**Problem:** The CLI needs to tell a running Safo instance to open a specific file.
   162→
   163→**Solution:** Register a custom URL scheme in Info.plist and handle it in SwiftUI.
   164→
   165→Info.plist:
   166→```xml
   167→<key>CFBundleURLTypes</key>
   168→<array>
   169→    <dict>
   170→        <key>CFBundleURLSchemes</key>
   171→        <array>
   172→            <string>safo</string>
   173→        </array>
   174→        <key>CFBundleURLName</key>
   175→        <string>com.significa.safo</string>
   176→    </dict>
   177→</array>
   178→```
   179→
   180→SwiftUI handler:
   181→```swift
   182→@main
   183→struct SafoApp: App {
   184→    var body: some Scene {
   185→        WindowGroup {
   186→            ContentView()
   187→                .onOpenURL { url in
   188→                    // url = safo://open?path=/absolute/path/to/file.md
   189→                    guard let components = URLComponents(url: url, resolvingAgainstBaseURL: false),
   190→                          let path = components.queryItems?.first(where: { $0.name == "path" })?.value
   191→                    else { return }
   192→                    viewModel.open(url: URL(fileURLWithPath: path))
   193→                }
   194→        }
   195→    }
   196→}
   197→```
   198→
   199→**Gotcha:** The path in the URL must be percent-encoded. The CLI must encode it.
   200→
   201→**Gotcha:** `onOpenURL` fires both when the app launches from a URL and when an already
   202→running app receives a URL. Handle both cases identically.
   203→
   204→---
   205→
   206→## 5. Single Instance Behavior
   207→
   208→**Problem:** Running `safo file.md` when Safo is already open should navigate to the new
   209→file in the existing window, not open a second window.
   210→
   211→**Solution:** Use `handlesExternalEvents` on the WindowGroup and configure the app to
   212→reuse the existing window.
   213→
   214→```swift
   215→@main
   216→struct SafoApp: App {
   217→    var body: some Scene {
   218→        WindowGroup {
   219→            ContentView()
   220→        }
   221→        .handlesExternalEvents(matching: Set(arrayLiteral: "*"))
   222→    }
   223→}
   224→```
   225→
   226→**Gotcha:** By default, `WindowGroup` creates a new window for each external event. The
   227→`handlesExternalEvents(matching:)` modifier with `"*"` routes all events to the existing
   228→window.
   229→
   230→**Gotcha:** Also set `NSSupportsAutomaticTermination` and `NSSupportsSuddenTermination` to
   231→`false` in Info.plist if you want predictable lifecycle behavior.
   232→
   233→---
   234→
   235→## 6. CLI Tool Implementation
   236→
   237→**Problem:** `safo file.md` must launch the app or send the file to a running instance.
   238→
   239→**Solution:** The CLI resolves the path to absolute, constructs a URL scheme, and opens it.
   240→
   241→```swift
   242→import Foundation
   243→
   244→@main
   245→struct SafoCLI {
   246→    static func main() {
   247→        guard CommandLine.arguments.count > 1 else {
   248→            print("Usage: safo <file.md>")
   249→            exit(1)
   250→        }
   251→
   252→        let rawPath = CommandLine.arguments[1]
   253→        let absolutePath: String
   254→
   255→        if rawPath.hasPrefix("/") {
   256→            absolutePath = rawPath
   257→        } else {
   258→            absolutePath = FileManager.default.currentDirectory + "/" + rawPath
   259→        }
   260→
   261→        // Verify file exists
   262→        guard FileManager.default.fileExists(atPath: absolutePath) else {
   263→            print("Error: file not found: \(absolutePath)")
   264→            exit(1)
   265→        }
   266→
   267→        // Construct URL scheme
   268→        let encoded = absolutePath.addingPercentEncoding(withAllowedCharacters: .urlQueryAllowed) ?? absolutePath
   269→        let url = "safo://open?path=\(encoded)"
   270→
   271→        // Open via macOS
   272→        let process = Process()
   273→        process.executableURL = URL(fileURLWithPath: "/usr/bin/open")
   274→        process.arguments = [url]
   275→        try? process.run()
   276→        process.waitUntilExit()
   277→    }
   278→}
   279→```
   280→
   281→**Gotcha:** Always resolve relative paths. The CLI's working directory is the user's
   282→terminal cwd, not the app's.
   283→
   284→**Gotcha:** Use `FileManager.default.currentDirectoryPath` (not `currentDirectory`).
   285→
   286→---
   287→
   288→## 7. Directory Scanning
   289→
   290→**Problem:** The sidebar needs all .md files in the current directory and subdirectories.
   291→
   292→**Solution:** Use `FileManager.enumerator` with a shallow depth or `contentsOfDirectory`
   293→recursively.
   294→
   295→```swift
   296→func scanMarkdownFiles(in directory: URL) -> [URL] {
   297→    let fm = FileManager.default
   298→    guard let enumerator = fm.enumerator(
   299→        at: directory,
   300→        includingPropertiesForKeys: [.isRegularFileKey],
   301→        options: [.skipsHiddenFiles]
   302→    ) else { return [] }
   303→
   304→    var files: [URL] = []
   305→    for case let fileURL as URL in enumerator {
   306→        if fileURL.pathExtension.lowercased() == "md" {
   307→            files.append(fileURL)
   308→        }
   309→    }
   310→    return files.sorted { $0.path < $1.path }
   311→}
   312→```
   313→
   314→**Gotcha:** Skip hidden files (`.skipsHiddenFiles`). Directories like `.git` contain
   315→markdown files you don't want to show.
   316→
   317→**Gotcha:** Sort alphabetically for predictable prev/next navigation.
   318→
   319→---
   320→
   321→## 8. Dark/Light Mode Theme Switching
   322→
   323→**Problem:** Safo must adapt all colors to the system appearance.
   324→
   325→**Solution:** Use `@Environment(\.colorScheme)` in views and make the Splash code theme
   326→dynamic.
   327→
   328→```swift
   329→struct MarkdownContentView: View {
   330→    @Environment(\.colorScheme) var colorScheme
   331→
   332→    var codeTheme: Splash.Theme {
   333→        colorScheme == .dark ? CodeTheme.dark : CodeTheme.light
   334→    }
   335→
   336→    var body: some View {
   337→        Markdown(content)
   338→            .markdownTheme(.safo)
   339→            .markdownCodeSyntaxHighlighter(
   340→                SplashCodeHighlighter(theme: codeTheme)
   341→            )
   342→    }
   343→}
   344→```
   345→
   346→**Gotcha:** MarkdownUI's built-in theme colors use SwiftUI semantic colors that adapt
   347→automatically. But Splash themes use fixed colors, so you need two Splash themes (dark
   348→and light) and switch based on colorScheme.
   349→
   350→---
   351→
   352→## 9. Copy Feedback
   353→
   354→**Problem:** After copying, the user needs brief visual confirmation.
   355→
   356→**Solution:** Temporarily change the copy button label from "Copy" to "Copied", then revert.
   357→
   358→```swift
   359→@State private var copied = false
   360→
   361→Button {
   362→    NSPasteboard.general.clearContents()
   363→    NSPasteboard.general.setString(content, forType: .string)
   364→    copied = true
   365→    DispatchQueue.main.asyncAfter(deadline: .now() + 1.5) {
   366→        copied = false
   367→    }
   368→} label: {
   369→    Text(copied ? "Copied" : "Copy")
   370→}
   371→```
   372→
   373→**Gotcha:** Use `NSPasteboard` (AppKit), not `UIPasteboard` (UIKit). This is macOS.
   374→

# Instructions for AI Assistant

You are building **Safo**, a native macOS markdown viewer app in SwiftUI. Safo is a read-only
viewer that opens from the terminal via `safo file.md`, renders markdown with rich typography,
and integrates with Claude Code via hooks.

## Project Context

Safo solves a workflow gap: developers using Claude Code generate markdown constantly but have no
lightweight, native way to preview it with rich typography. Terminal renderers (Glow, mdcat) are
monospaced. GUI apps (Typora, Marked 2) are heavy and disconnected from the terminal. Safo is
CLI-first, native SwiftUI, and designed for the generate-preview-iterate loop.

**Tech Stack:**
- Swift 5.9+, macOS 14+ (Sonoma)
- SwiftUI (app lifecycle, views, state management)
- Swift Package Manager (dependencies, build)
- MarkdownUI (gonzalezreal/swift-markdown-ui) for markdown rendering
- Splash (JohnSundell/Splash) for syntax highlighting
- No backend. No network calls. Local files only.

## Documentation Structure

```
docs/
├── INSTRUCTIONS.md                    # You are here
├── 00-roadmap.md                      # Phased task list
├── 01-one-pager.md                    # Project overview and scope
├── 02-architecture.md                 # Architecture, models, file structure
├── 03-design-tokens.md                # Typography, colors, spacing
├── 04-ui-components.md                # SwiftUI view specifications
├── patterns-and-conventions.md        # Implementation patterns and gotchas
├── standards/
│   ├── code-conventions.md            # Swift naming, style, patterns
│   ├── colocation.md                  # Where to put code
│   └── swiftui-patterns.md            # SwiftUI-specific patterns
└── PRODUCT-BRIEF.md                   # Product definition (reference only)
```

## Required Reading (In Order)

### Before Writing ANY Code
1. `docs/standards/code-conventions.md`
2. `docs/standards/colocation.md`
3. `docs/standards/swiftui-patterns.md`
4. `docs/03-design-tokens.md`

### Before Each Phase
1. `docs/patterns-and-conventions.md`: known solutions to known problems
2. `docs/00-roadmap.md`: current task
3. Relevant spec files for the phase

## Working with the Roadmap

### Branching (mandatory)
1. Each phase lives on its own branch: `feature/phase-1-core-rendering`, `feature/phase-2-navigation`, `feature/phase-3-cli-integration`.
2. Create the branch from `main` before starting the phase.
3. Commit frequently: every completed task (or meaningful chunk of work) gets a commit.
4. At the end of each phase: PR to main, review, merge. Then branch the next phase from updated main.

### Rules
1. Work in order. Complete Phase 1 before Phase 2.
2. One task at a time.
3. Mark tasks as done: `[ ]` to `[x]`.
4. Write phase summaries after completing all tasks in a phase.
5. Commit after every completed task. Do not batch multiple tasks into one commit.

### Task Completion Checklist
- [ ] Code compiles without errors (`swift build`)
- [ ] Feature works as described
- [ ] Follows standards in `docs/standards/`
- [ ] Uses design tokens (no hardcoded values)
- [ ] Dark and light mode both render correctly

### Quality Gates (mandatory, after each phase)
Before merging a phase branch to main, you MUST:
1. Invoke `superpowers:verification-before-completion` to confirm all tasks work and compile.
2. Invoke `superpowers:requesting-code-review` for a code review against standards and roadmap.

# Code Conventions

> Consistency enables speed. These conventions are non-negotiable.

## Naming

### Files & Folders
| Type | Convention | Example |
|------|-----------|---------|
| Views | `PascalCase.swift` | `ContentView.swift` |
| ViewModels | `PascalCase.swift` | `DocumentViewModel.swift` |
| Models | `PascalCase.swift` | `MarkdownDocument.swift` |
| Theme | `PascalCase.swift` | `SafoTheme.swift` |
| Utilities | `PascalCase.swift` | `FileWatcher.swift` |
| Constants | `PascalCase.swift` | `Tokens.swift` |

### Variables & Functions
| Type | Convention | Example |
|------|-----------|---------|
| Types/Structs/Classes | `PascalCase` | `MarkdownDocument` |
| Functions/Methods | `camelCase` | `scanMarkdownFiles()` |
| Properties | `camelCase` | `currentFile` |
| Constants (global) | `camelCase` in enum namespace | `Tokens.Typography.h1Size` |
| Booleans | `is/has/should/can` prefix | `isLoading`, `hasPrevious` |
| Closures | `on` prefix for callbacks | `onChange`, `onSelect` |
| @Published | descriptive noun | `document`, `sidebarVisible` |

## Swift

- `struct` over `class` unless reference semantics needed (ViewModels are `class`)
- `let` over `var` when value doesn't change
- No force unwraps (`!`). Use `guard let` or optional chaining.
- No `Any`. Use protocols or generics.
- Use `@MainActor` on ViewModels and any code that touches UI state
- Prefer computed properties over methods when no side effects and no parameters
- Use access control: `private` by default, only expose what's needed

## SwiftUI

- Views are structs, always
- Keep views small (under 100 lines). Extract subviews.
- Use `@StateObject` for ViewModel ownership, `@ObservedObject` for passing down
- Use `@Environment` for system values (colorScheme, etc.)
- Prefer `.task` over `.onAppear` for async work
- Never do heavy computation in `body`. Use computed properties or ViewModel.

## Imports

Order: Foundation/SwiftUI > third-party packages > local modules

```swift
import SwiftUI
import MarkdownUI
import Splash
```

## Comments

Explain WHY, not WHAT. No obvious comments. TODO with context:

```swift
// TODO(v2): Support image rendering when MarkdownUI adds lazy loading
```

## Error Handling

- Define errors as enum conforming to `Error`
- Handle errors at the ViewModel level, expose as `@Published var error: SafoError?`
- Views display errors, never handle them
- Never use `try!` or `fatalError` in production paths

# Code Colocation

> Keep code as close as possible to where it's used.

## Core Rule

- Used in 1 view only: keep in that view file
- Used in 2+ places: move to the appropriate shared location
- "Might be used later": keep colocated until actual reuse

## Decision Tree

### Models
Always centralized: `Models/`

### ViewModels
Always centralized: `ViewModels/`
One ViewModel per major feature, not per view.

### Views
Always in `Views/`
Extract subviews when a view exceeds 100 lines or when a section is logically independent.

### Theme
Always centralized: `Theme/`
All design tokens, markdown theme, and code theme live here.

### Utilities
Always centralized: `Utilities/`
General-purpose helpers that are not view-specific.

### Types
- View-specific types: define in the view file
- Shared types (used in models, ViewModels, or multiple views): `Models/`

### Extensions
- Type-specific extension used in 1 place: colocate
- Broadly useful extension: `Utilities/` with descriptive filename

## File Structure Reference

```
Sources/Safo/
├── SafoApp.swift              # App entry point only
├── AppDelegate.swift          # Window management only
├── Models/                    # Data structures
├── ViewModels/                # Business logic, state
├── Views/                     # UI
├── Theme/                     # Visual tokens and themes
└── Utilities/                 # Helpers, file watching, errors
```

No nested folders beyond this. Keep flat within each folder.

1→# SwiftUI Patterns
     2→
     3→Patterns specific to SwiftUI macOS development in Safo.
     4→
     5→## App Lifecycle
     6→
     7→Safo uses the SwiftUI App lifecycle with an AppDelegate adapter for window management.
     8→
     9→```swift
    10→@main
    11→struct SafoApp: App {
    12→    @NSApplicationDelegateAdaptor(AppDelegate.self) var appDelegate
    13→
    14→    var body: some Scene {
    15→        WindowGroup { ... }
    16→    }
    17→}
    18→```
    19→
    20→Use `@NSApplicationDelegateAdaptor` only for things SwiftUI can't do natively:
    21→window positioning, URL scheme handling at the NSApplication level.
    22→
    23→## State Management
    24→
    25→### ViewModel Pattern
    26→```
    27→SafoApp (owns @StateObject DocumentViewModel)
    28→└── ContentView (receives @ObservedObject)
    29→    ├── SidebarView (receives @ObservedObject)
    30→    ├── MarkdownContentView (receives @ObservedObject)
    31→    └── ToolbarItems (receives @ObservedObject)
    32→```
    33→
    34→One ViewModel (`DocumentViewModel`) owns all app state. Views observe it.
    35→No child ViewModels. No stores. Keep it simple.
    36→
    37→### State Ownership Rules
    38→| Property wrapper | When |
    39→|-----------------|------|
    40→| `@StateObject` | Creating the ViewModel (only in SafoApp or ContentView) |
    41→| `@ObservedObject` | Receiving the ViewModel from parent |
    42→| `@State` | View-local UI state (sidebar animation, hover, copied feedback) |
    43→| `@Environment` | System values (colorScheme, dismiss) |
    44→| `@Binding` | Passing mutable state to child without ViewModel |
    45→
    46→## Navigation
    47→
    48→No router. No NavigationStack. Safo has one screen with an optional sidebar.
    49→
    50→Sidebar visibility is a boolean on the ViewModel. File navigation is handled by
    51→the ViewModel (prev/next/goTo). Views just call ViewModel methods.
    52→
    53→## Keyboard Shortcuts
    54→
    55→Use `.keyboardShortcut` on buttons in the toolbar:
    56→
    57→```swift
    58→Button("Previous") { viewModel.navigateToPrevious() }
    59→    .keyboardShortcut("[", modifiers: .command)
    60→```
    61→
    62→For global shortcuts not tied to visible buttons, use `.onKeyPress` (macOS 14+)
    63→or add hidden buttons.
    64→
    65→## Window Management
    66→
    67→Window-level operations (positioning, sizing) go through AppDelegate.
    68→Views never touch NSWindow directly.
    69→
    70→```swift
    71→// In AppDelegate
    72→func positionWindow() {
    73→    guard let window = NSApplication.shared.windows.first else { return }
    74→    // position logic
    75→}
    76→```
    77→
    78→## Toolbar
    79→
    80→Use SwiftUI's `.toolbar` modifier on the main content view:
    81→
    82→```swift
    83→.toolbar {
    84→    ToolbarItemGroup(placement: .navigation) {
    85→        // sidebar toggle, prev/next
    86→    }
    87→    ToolbarItem(placement: .principal) {
    88→        // file info
    89→    }
    90→    ToolbarItemGroup(placement: .primaryAction) {
    91→        // copy button
    92→    }
    93→}
    94→```
    95→
    96→## Performance
    97→
    98→- MarkdownUI re-renders when the content string changes. This is fine for normal files.
    99→  For very large files (10K+ lines), consider debouncing the file watcher reload.
   100→- Don't wrap the Markdown view in unnecessary containers. Keep the view hierarchy shallow.
   101→- Use `Equatable` on models to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
   102→

# Architecture

## Overview

Safo has two targets: a macOS SwiftUI app (`Safo`) and a CLI tool (`safo`). The CLI launches
the app or communicates with a running instance. The app renders markdown files using MarkdownUI
with a custom theme and watches the file system for changes.

## Dependencies

| Package | Purpose | Version |
|---------|---------|---------|
| [MarkdownUI](https://github.com/gonzalezreal/swift-markdown-ui) | GFM markdown rendering in SwiftUI | 2.4+ |
| [Splash](https://github.com/JohnSundell/Splash) | Swift-native syntax highlighting | 0.16+ |

No other dependencies. Keep it minimal.

## Targets

### Safo (macOS App)
- SwiftUI app using `@main` App protocol
- macOS 14+ (Sonoma)
- Renders markdown, manages window, watches files

### safo (CLI Tool)
- Swift executable
- Launches the app via `open` or sends file path to running instance via URL scheme
- Resolves relative paths to absolute before sending

## URL Scheme

`safo://open?path=/absolute/path/to/file.md`

The CLI tool constructs this URL and opens it. The app handles it via `onOpenURL`.

## Data Flow

```
Terminal                    CLI (safo)                  App (Safo)
───────                    ──────────                  ──────────
safo file.md  ──────────>  Resolve path  ──────────>  onOpenURL / launch args
                           Build URL                        │
                           open URL                         ▼
                                                    DocumentViewModel
                                                    ├── loads file content
                                                    ├── starts FileWatcher
                                                    └── scans directory
                                                            │
                                                            ▼
                                                    ContentView
                                                    ├── MarkdownContentView (rendered MD)
                                                    ├── SidebarView (file list)
                                                    └── ToolbarView (controls)
```

## Models

### MarkdownDocument
```swift
struct MarkdownDocument: Identifiable, Equatable {
    let id: URL           // file URL (unique identifier)
    let url: URL          // absolute file URL
    var content: String   // raw markdown content
    var lastModified: Date

    var fileName: String  // derived: url.lastPathComponent
    var relativePath: String // derived: relative to root directory
}
```

### DirectoryListing
```swift
struct DirectoryListing {
    let rootURL: URL                    // base directory
    var files: [URL]                    // all .md files, sorted alphabetically
    var currentIndex: Int               // index of current file in list

    var currentFile: URL?               // files[currentIndex]
    var hasPrevious: Bool               // currentIndex > 0
    var hasNext: Bool                   // currentIndex < files.count - 1

    mutating func goToNext()
    mutating func goToPrevious()
    mutating func goTo(url: URL)
}
```

## ViewModels

### DocumentViewModel (ObservableObject)
```swift
@MainActor
class DocumentViewModel: ObservableObject {
    @Published var document: MarkdownDocument?
    @Published var directoryListing: DirectoryListing?
    @Published var sidebarVisible: Bool = false
    @Published var error: SafoError?

    private var fileWatcher: FileWatcher?

    func open(url: URL)                 // load file, scan directory, start watching
    func navigateToNext()               // next .md in directory
    func navigateToPrevious()           // previous .md in directory
    func navigateTo(url: URL)           // specific file in directory
    func copyToClipboard()              // copy raw markdown to system clipboard
    func toggleSidebar()                // show/hide sidebar
}
```

### FileWatcher
```swift
class FileWatcher {
    // Uses DispatchSource.makeFileSystemObjectSource to watch file changes
    // Calls onChange callback when file is modified
    // Automatically stops when deallocated

    init(url: URL, onChange: @escaping () -> Void)
    func start()
    func stop()
}
```

## App Lifecycle

### Launch with file argument
1. `SafoApp.init` checks for launch arguments or URL scheme
2. Creates `DocumentViewModel`
3. Calls `viewModel.open(url:)` with the file path
4. `WindowGroup` renders `ContentView`
5. `AppDelegate` positions window (right side, 40% width, full height)

### Receive file while running
1. `onOpenURL` receives `safo://open?path=...`
2. Extracts path, calls `viewModel.open(url:)`
3. Same window navigates to new file

### File changes on disk
1. `FileWatcher` detects modification
2. Reloads file content
3. `document.content` updates
4. SwiftUI re-renders the markdown view

## Error States

| Error | Behavior |
|-------|----------|
| File not found | Show message in content area: "File not found: {path}" |
| Not a .md file | Show message: "Safo only opens markdown files" |
| Permission denied | Show message: "Cannot read file: permission denied" |
| Empty file | Show message: "Empty file" (subtle, not error-styled) |
| File deleted while viewing | Show message: "File was deleted", stop watcher |

## File Structure

```
safo/
├── Package.swift                      # SPM manifest

content.thinking:
Wait, actually for a macOS SwiftUI app built via SPM, Info.plist handling is different. Let me think about this.

For SPM-based macOS apps, the Info.plist is not automatically picked up like in Xcode projects. The `resources` approach in Package.swift copies files as bundle resources, but that's not the same as the app's Info.plist.

For SPM executables, the Info.plist needs to be placed differently. Actually, for a SwiftUI app built with `swift build`, there's no automatic bundling of Info.plist. The URL scheme registration via Info.plist only works when the app is built as a proper .app bundle.
 
So the roadmap's Resources/Info.plist structure assumes a proper .app bundle, but `swift build` produces a plain executable. Looking at the patterns, the URL scheme approach in patterns #4-6 all depend on that bundled structure, which means I need to reconsider whether a CLI tool approach might be more practical for an SPM-based project.

The real constraint here is that SPM doesn't allow resources outside the target's directory, so I can't reference `../../Resources/Info.plist` in Package.swift anyway. The resources need to live within the target itself.

For the URL scheme to actually function, the app needs to be built as a proper .app bundle and registered with Launch Services—just having an Info.plist isn't enough. With SPM and `swift build`, I'm getting an executable, not a bundle, which means the URL scheme registration won't happen automatically.

I could sidestep this by having the CLI pass the file path as a launch argument instead of using the URL scheme, but the spec explicitly requires URL scheme support. So I'll stick with the original plan: create the Info.plist, configure Package.swift to include it as a resource, and accept that the URL scheme will only work once the app is properly built as a .app bundle through xcodebuild or a similar build system. The Info.plist is really just a template for the actual app bundle—SPM won't handle bundling it directly, so I'll need to revert my Package.swift changes and rely on either `xcodebuild` or the `open -a` approach to test the URL scheme functionality in practice.

Based on your current configuration and the hook examples in your settings, here's what I can document about Claude Code hooks:

## Hook Configuration Format

**Location:** `.claude/settings.json` under the `hooks` object

**JSON Structure:**
```json
{
  "hooks": {
    "EVENT_NAME": [
      {
        "matcher": "ToolName or glob pattern",
        "hooks": [
          {
            "type": "command",
            "command": "your command here"
          }
        ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
```

## Available Hook Events

Based on your configuration, these events are available:

1. **SessionStart** - Fires when a Claude Code session begins
2. **SessionEnd** - Fires when a Claude Code session ends
3. **UserPromptSubmit** - Fires when the user submits a prompt
4. **Stop** - Fires when Claude Code stops
5. **PreToolUse** - Fires before a tool is executed (matcher filters by tool name)
6. **PostToolUse** - Fires after a tool is executed (matcher filters by tool name)

## Answer to Your Specific Question

For a hook that runs after a file is written, based on the available events, you would use **PostToolUse** with a file-writing tool matcher. However, looking at your current setup, there isn't a dedicated "FileWrite" hook event visible in your configuration.

Your current usage shows:
- `PostToolUse` with `"matcher": "TodoWrite"` for post-todo operations
- `PostToolUse` with `"matcher": "Task"` for post-task operations

This suggests the `matcher` field accepts tool/operation names to filter which PostToolUse triggers apply.

To see the complete list of available hook events and whether there's a dedicated file write event, I'd recommend:
1. Check `/usr/local/bin/claude-code` or your installation path for the complete hook documentation
2. Run `claude-code --help` to see if there's a hooks reference
3. Use `/feedback` to request documentation if the complete hook events list isn't documented

Your settings file location is correct: **`/Users/andrefurt/code/safo/.claude/settings.json`** (or `~/.claude/settings.json` for global configuration).

## Phase 3: CLI, Integration & Polish (10 tasks)

**Branch:** `feature/phase-3-cli-integration` (from updated `main` after Phase 2 merge)

**Goal:** `safo file.md` works from terminal. Single instance behavior. Claude Code hook
documented. All edge cases handled. App is usable for daily work.

**Depends on:** Phase 2
**Key docs:** `02-architecture.md`

### Gotchas
- See patterns #4 (URL scheme), #5 (single instance), #6 (CLI tool)
- Path encoding is critical: spaces and special characters in file paths

### Tasks

- [ ] 3.1: Create `Resources/Info.plist` with URL scheme registration (`safo://`). Add `CFBundleURLTypes` with scheme `safo` and name `com.significa.safo`. Set `LSUIElement` to false (visible in dock when running).

- [ ] 3.2: Update `SafoApp.swift` with `.onOpenURL` handler. Parse `safo://open?path=...` URL, extract path, call `viewModel.open(url:)`. Also handle launch arguments: if `CommandLine.arguments` contains a file path, open it on launch. See patterns #4.

- [ ] 3.3: Implement single instance behavior. Add `.handlesExternalEvents(matching:)` to WindowGroup so new URLs navigate in the existing window instead of opening a new one. See patterns #5.

- [ ] 3.4: Create `Sources/safo-cli/SafoCLI.swift`. Accept file path argument, resolve to absolute path, verify file exists and is .md, construct `safo://` URL, open via `Process` calling `/usr/bin/open`. See patterns #6. Handle errors: no argument, file not found, not .md.

- [ ] 3.5: Test end-to-end CLI flow. Build both targets. Run `safo test.md` from terminal. Verify: app opens, file renders, window positions correctly. Run again with different file. Verify: same window navigates to new file.

## Phase 1: Setup & Core Rendering (13 tasks)

**Branch:** `feature/phase-1-core-rendering` (from `main`)

**Goal:** App launches, renders a hardcoded markdown string with full custom theme
(typography, colors, code highlighting), adapts to dark/light mode. Window positions

**Key docs:** `02-architecture.md`, `03-design-tokens.md`, `04-ui-components.md`

### Tasks

### Phase 1 Summary

Phase 1 established the project foundation and core rendering pipeline.

**What was built:**
- `Package.swift` with two targets (Safo app, safo-cli) and dependencies (MarkdownUI 2.4.1, Splash 0.16.0)
- SwiftUI app lifecycle with `@NSApplicationDelegateAdaptor` for window positioning (40% width, right side, full height)
- Complete design token system (`Tokens.swift`) covering typography, spacing, layout, colors, code colors, and animation values
- Custom MarkdownUI theme (`SafoTheme.swift`) styling all block and inline elements: 6 heading levels with distinct sizes/weights/tracking, paragraphs with 1.65 line spacing, blockquotes with left border, styled tables, lists, horizontal rules, links, strong/emphasis/strikethrough, and inline code

- `MarkdownContentView` with scrollable, centered (720pt max), padded content that switches Splash theme based on system color scheme
- Comprehensive test markdown fixture covering all supported elements

**Architecture decisions:**
- Used absolute font sizes in theme (not relative em units) since the design spec defines exact point sizes
- Splash `TextOutputFormat` adapted for macOS (NSColor instead of UIColor)
- Code theme switching driven by `@Environment(\.colorScheme)` for automatic dark/light adaptation
- All colors are semantic SwiftUI colors or token-defined, no hardcoded values in views

# Verification Before Completion

## Overview

Claiming work is complete without verification is dishonesty, not efficiency.

**Core principle:** Evidence before claims, always.

**Violating the letter of this rule is violating the spirit of this rule.**

## The Iron Law

```
NO COMPLETION CLAIMS WITHOUT FRESH VERIFICATION EVIDENCE
```

If you haven't run the verification command in this message, you cannot claim it passes.

## The Gate Function

```
BEFORE claiming any status or expressing satisfaction:

1. IDENTIFY: What command proves this claim?
2. RUN: Execute the FULL command (fresh, complete)
3. READ: Full output, check exit code, count failures
4. VERIFY: Does output confirm the claim?
   - If NO: State actual status with evidence
   - If YES: State claim WITH evidence
5. ONLY THEN: Make the claim

Skip any step = lying, not verifying
```

## Common Failures

| Claim | Requires | Not Sufficient |
|-------|----------|----------------|
| Tests pass | Test command output: 0 failures | Previous run, "should pass" |
| Linter clean | Linter output: 0 errors | Partial check, extrapolation |
| Build succeeds | Build command: exit 0 | Linter passing, logs look good |
| Bug fixed | Test original symptom: passes | Code changed, assumed fixed |
| Regression test works | Red-green cycle verified | Test passes once |
| Agent completed | VCS diff shows changes | Agent reports "success" |
| Requirements met | Line-by-line checklist | Tests passing |

## Red Flags - STOP

- Using "should", "probably", "seems to"
- Expressing satisfaction before verification ("Great!", "Perfect!", "Done!", etc.)
- About to commit/push/PR without verification
- Trusting agent success reports
- Relying on partial verification
- Thinking "just this once"
- Tired and wanting work over
- **ANY wording implying success without having run verification**

## Rationalization Prevention

| Excuse | Reality |
|--------|---------|
| "Should work now" | RUN the verification |
| "I'm confident" | Confidence ≠ evidence |
| "Just this once" | No exceptions |
| "Linter passed" | Linter ≠ compiler |
| "Agent said success" | Verify independently |
| "I'm tired" | Exhaustion ≠ excuse |
| "Partial check is enough" | Partial proves nothing |
| "Different words so rule doesn't apply" | Spirit over letter |

## Key Patterns

**Tests:**
```
✅ [Run test command] [See: 34/34 pass] "All tests pass"
❌ "Should pass now" / "Looks correct"
```

**Regression tests (TDD Red-Green):**
```
✅ Write → Run (pass) → Revert fix → Run (MUST FAIL) → Restore → Run (pass)
❌ "I've written a regression test" (without red-green verification)
```

**Build:**
```
✅ [Run build] [See: exit 0] "Build passes"
❌ "Linter passed" (linter doesn't check compilation)
```

**Requirements:**
```
✅ Re-read plan → Create checklist → Verify each → Report gaps or completion
❌ "Tests pass, phase complete"
```

**Agent delegation:**
```
✅ Agent reports success → Check VCS diff → Verify changes → Report actual state
❌ Trust agent report
```

## Why This Matters

From 24 failure memories:
- your human partner said "I don't believe you" - trust broken
- Undefined functions shipped - would crash
- Missing requirements shipped - incomplete features
- Time wasted on false completion → redirect → rework
- Violates: "Honesty is a core value. If you lie, you'll be replaced."

## When To Apply

**ALWAYS before:**
- ANY variation of success/completion claims
- ANY expression of satisfaction
- ANY positive statement about work state
- Committing, PR creation, task completion
- Moving to next task
- Delegating to agents

**Rule applies to:**
- Exact phrases
- Paraphrases and synonyms
- Implications of success
- ANY communication suggesting completion/correctness

## The Bottom Line

**No shortcuts for verification.**

Run the command. Read the output. THEN claim the result.

This is non-negotiable.

1→# Claude Code Hook
     2→
     3→Auto-preview markdown files in Safo whenever Claude Code writes or edits a `.md` file.
     4→
     5→## Setup
     6→
     7→Add this hook to your Claude Code settings. You can configure it at project level (`.claude/settings.json`) or globally (`~/.claude/settings.json`).
     8→
     9→### Hook Configuration
    10→
    11→```json
    12→{
    13→  "hooks": {
    14→    "PostToolUse": [
    15→      {
    16→        "matcher": "Write",
    17→        "hooks": [
    18→          {
    19→            "type": "command",
    20→            "command": "case \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" in *.md|*.markdown) safo \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" ;; esac"
    21→          }
    22→        ]
    23→      },
    24→      {
    25→        "matcher": "Edit",
    26→        "hooks": [
    27→          {
    28→            "type": "command",
    29→            "command": "case \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" in *.md|*.markdown) safo \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" ;; esac"
    30→          }
    31→        ]
    32→      }
    33→    ]
    34→  }
    35→}
    36→```
    37→
    38→## Prerequisites
    39→
    40→The `safo` CLI binary must be in your PATH. After building:
    41→
    42→```sh
    43→swift build -c release
    44→cp .build/release/safo-cli /usr/local/bin/safo
    45→```
    46→
    47→## How It Works
    48→
    49→1. Claude Code writes or edits a file
    50→2. The PostToolUse hook fires after the tool completes
    51→3. The hook checks if the file has a `.md` or `.markdown` extension
    52→4. If it matches, it runs `safo <path>` which opens or navigates the Safo app to that file
    53→5. If Safo is already running, it reuses the existing window (single instance behavior)
    54→
    55→## Notes
    56→
    57→- The hook only triggers for markdown files. All other file types are ignored.
    58→- If the Safo app is not installed as a .app bundle with URL scheme registration, the CLI falls back to launching the binary directly via launch arguments.
    59→- The hook runs asynchronously and does not block Claude Code.
    60→

# Requesting Code Review

Dispatch superpowers:code-reviewer subagent to catch issues before they cascade.

**Core principle:** Review early, review often.

## When to Request Review

**Mandatory:**
- After each task in subagent-driven development
- After completing major feature
- Before merge to main

**Optional but valuable:**
- When stuck (fresh perspective)
- Before refactoring (baseline check)
- After fixing complex bug

## How to Request

**1. Get git SHAs:**
```bash
BASE_SHA=$(git rev-parse HEAD~1)  # or origin/main
HEAD_SHA=$(git rev-parse HEAD)
```

**2. Dispatch code-reviewer subagent:**

Use Task tool with superpowers:code-reviewer type, fill template at `code-reviewer.md`

**Placeholders:**
- `{WHAT_WAS_IMPLEMENTED}` - What you just built
- `{PLAN_OR_REQUIREMENTS}` - What it should do
- `{BASE_SHA}` - Starting commit
- `{HEAD_SHA}` - Ending commit
- `{DESCRIPTION}` - Brief summary

**3. Act on feedback:**
- Fix Critical issues immediately
- Fix Important issues before proceeding
- Note Minor issues for later
- Push back if reviewer is wrong (with reasoning)

## Example

```
[Just completed Task 2: Add verification function]

You: Let me request code review before proceeding.

BASE_SHA=$(git log --oneline | grep "Task 1" | head -1 | awk '{print }')
HEAD_SHA=$(git rev-parse HEAD)

[Dispatch superpowers:code-reviewer subagent]
  WHAT_WAS_IMPLEMENTED: Verification and repair functions for conversation index
  PLAN_OR_REQUIREMENTS: Task 2 from docs/plans/deployment-plan.md
  BASE_SHA: a7981ec
  HEAD_SHA: 3df7661
  DESCRIPTION: Added verifyIndex() and repairIndex() with 4 issue types

[Subagent returns]:
  Strengths: Clean architecture, real tests
  Issues:
    Important: Missing progress indicators
    Minor: Magic number (100) for reporting interval
  Assessment: Ready to proceed

You: [Fix progress indicators]
[Continue to Task 3]
```

## Integration with Workflows

**Subagent-Driven Development:**
- Review after EACH task
- Catch issues before they compound
- Fix before moving to next task

**Executing Plans:**
- Review after each batch (3 tasks)
- Get feedback, apply, continue

**Ad-Hoc Development:**
- Review before merge
- Review when stuck

## Red Flags

**Never:**
- Skip review because "it's simple"
- Ignore Critical issues
- Proceed with unfixed Important issues
- Argue with valid technical feedback

**If reviewer wrong:**
- Push back with technical reasoning
- Show code/tests that prove it works
- Request clarification

See template at: requesting-code-review/code-reviewer.md

1→# Code Conventions
     2→
     3→> Consistency enables speed. These conventions are non-negotiable.
     4→
     5→## Naming
     6→
     7→### Files & Folders
     8→| Type | Convention | Example |
     9→|------|-----------|---------|
    10→| Views | `PascalCase.swift` | `ContentView.swift` |
    11→| ViewModels | `PascalCase.swift` | `DocumentViewModel.swift` |
    12→| Models | `PascalCase.swift` | `MarkdownDocument.swift` |
    13→| Theme | `PascalCase.swift` | `SafoTheme.swift` |
    14→| Utilities | `PascalCase.swift` | `FileWatcher.swift` |
    15→| Constants | `PascalCase.swift` | `Tokens.swift` |
    16→
    17→### Variables & Functions
    18→| Type | Convention | Example |
    19→|------|-----------|---------|
    20→| Types/Structs/Classes | `PascalCase` | `MarkdownDocument` |
    21→| Functions/Methods | `camelCase` | `scanMarkdownFiles()` |
    22→| Properties | `camelCase` | `currentFile` |
    23→| Constants (global) | `camelCase` in enum namespace | `Tokens.Typography.h1Size` |
    24→| Booleans | `is/has/should/can` prefix | `isLoading`, `hasPrevious` |
    25→| Closures | `on` prefix for callbacks | `onChange`, `onSelect` |
    26→| @Published | descriptive noun | `document`, `sidebarVisible` |
    27→
    28→## Swift
    29→
    30→- `struct` over `class` unless reference semantics needed (ViewModels are `class`)
    31→- `let` over `var` when value doesn't change
    32→- No force unwraps (`!`). Use `guard let` or optional chaining.
    33→- No `Any`. Use protocols or generics.
    34→- Use `@MainActor` on ViewModels and any code that touches UI state
    35→- Prefer computed properties over methods when no side effects and no parameters
    36→- Use access control: `private` by default, only expose what's needed
    37→
    38→## SwiftUI
    39→
    40→- Views are structs, always
    41→- Keep views small (under 100 lines). Extract subviews.
    42→- Use `@StateObject` for ViewModel ownership, `@ObservedObject` for passing down
    43→- Use `@Environment` for system values (colorScheme, etc.)
    44→- Prefer `.task` over `.onAppear` for async work
    45→- Never do heavy computation in `body`. Use computed properties or ViewModel.
    46→
    47→## Imports
    48→
    49→Order: Foundation/SwiftUI > third-party packages > local modules
    50→
    51→```swift
    52→import SwiftUI
    53→import MarkdownUI
    54→import Splash
    55→```
    56→
    57→## Comments
    58→
    59→Explain WHY, not WHAT. No obvious comments. TODO with context:
    60→
    61→```swift
    62→// TODO(v2): Support image rendering when MarkdownUI adds lazy loading
    63→```
    64→
    65→## Error Handling
    66→
    67→- Define errors as enum conforming to `Error`
    68→- Handle errors at the ViewModel level, expose as `@Published var error: SafoError?`
    69→- Views display errors, never handle them
    70→- Never use `try!` or `fatalError` in production paths
    71→

1→# Code Colocation
     2→
     3→> Keep code as close as possible to where it's used.
     4→
     5→## Core Rule
     6→
     7→- Used in 1 view only: keep in that view file
     8→- Used in 2+ places: move to the appropriate shared location
     9→- "Might be used later": keep colocated until actual reuse
    10→
    11→## Decision Tree
    12→
    13→### Models
    14→Always centralized: `Models/`
    15→
    16→### ViewModels
    17→Always centralized: `ViewModels/`
    18→One ViewModel per major feature, not per view.
    19→
    20→### Views
    21→Always in `Views/`
    22→Extract subviews when a view exceeds 100 lines or when a section is logically independent.
    23→
    24→### Theme
    25→Always centralized: `Theme/`
    26→All design tokens, markdown theme, and code theme live here.
    27→
    28→### Utilities
    29→Always centralized: `Utilities/`
    30→General-purpose helpers that are not view-specific.
    31→
    32→### Types
    33→- View-specific types: define in the view file
    34→- Shared types (used in models, ViewModels, or multiple views): `Models/`
    35→
    36→### Extensions
    37→- Type-specific extension used in 1 place: colocate
    38→- Broadly useful extension: `Utilities/` with descriptive filename
    39→
    40→## File Structure Reference
    41→
    42→```
    43→Sources/Safo/
    44→├── SafoApp.swift              # App entry point only
    45→├── AppDelegate.swift          # Window management only
    46→├── Models/                    # Data structures
    47→├── ViewModels/                # Business logic, state
    48→├── Views/                     # UI
    49→├── Theme/                     # Visual tokens and themes
    50→└── Utilities/                 # Helpers, file watching, errors
    51→```
    52→
    53→No nested folders beyond this. Keep flat within each folder.
    54→

1→# SwiftUI Patterns
     2→
     3→Patterns specific to SwiftUI macOS development in Safo.
     4→
     5→## App Lifecycle
     6→
     7→Safo uses the SwiftUI App lifecycle with an AppDelegate adapter for window management.
     8→
     9→```swift
    10→@main
    11→struct SafoApp: App {
    12→    @NSApplicationDelegateAdaptor(AppDelegate.self) var appDelegate
    13→
    14→    var body: some Scene {
    15→        WindowGroup { ... }
    16→    }
    17→}
    18→```
    19→
    20→Use `@NSApplicationDelegateAdaptor` only for things SwiftUI can't do natively:
    21→window positioning, URL scheme handling at the NSApplication level.
    22→
    23→## State Management
    24→
    25→### ViewModel Pattern
    26→```
    27→SafoApp (owns @StateObject DocumentViewModel)
    28→└── ContentView (receives @ObservedObject)
    29→    ├── SidebarView (receives @ObservedObject)
    30→    ├── MarkdownContentView (receives @ObservedObject)
    31→    └── ToolbarItems (receives @ObservedObject)
    32→```
    33→
    34→One ViewModel (`DocumentViewModel`) owns all app state. Views observe it.
    35→No child ViewModels. No stores. Keep it simple.
    36→
    37→### State Ownership Rules
    38→| Property wrapper | When |
    39→|-----------------|------|
    40→| `@StateObject` | Creating the ViewModel (only in SafoApp or ContentView) |
    41→| `@ObservedObject` | Receiving the ViewModel from parent |
    42→| `@State` | View-local UI state (sidebar animation, hover, copied feedback) |
    43→| `@Environment` | System values (colorScheme, dismiss) |
    44→| `@Binding` | Passing mutable state to child without ViewModel |
    45→
    46→## Navigation
    47→
    48→No router. No NavigationStack. Safo has one screen with an optional sidebar.
    49→
    50→Sidebar visibility is a boolean on the ViewModel. File navigation is handled by
    51→the ViewModel (prev/next/goTo). Views just call ViewModel methods.
    52→
    53→## Keyboard Shortcuts
    54→
    55→Use `.keyboardShortcut` on buttons in the toolbar:
    56→
    57→```swift
    58→Button("Previous") { viewModel.navigateToPrevious() }
    59→    .keyboardShortcut("[", modifiers: .command)
    60→```
    61→
    62→For global shortcuts not tied to visible buttons, use `.onKeyPress` (macOS 14+)
    63→or add hidden buttons.
    64→
    65→## Window Management
    66→
    67→Window-level operations (positioning, sizing) go through AppDelegate.
    68→Views never touch NSWindow directly.
    69→
    70→```swift
    71→// In AppDelegate
    72→func positionWindow() {
    73→    guard let window = NSApplication.shared.windows.first else { return }
    74→    // position logic
    75→}
    76→```
    77→
    78→## Toolbar
    79→
    80→Use SwiftUI's `.toolbar` modifier on the main content view:
    81→
    82→```swift
    83→.toolbar {
    84→    ToolbarItemGroup(placement: .navigation) {
    85→        // sidebar toggle, prev/next
    86→    }
    87→    ToolbarItem(placement: .principal) {
    88→        // file info
    89→    }
    90→    ToolbarItemGroup(placement: .primaryAction) {
    91→        // copy button
    92→    }
    93→}
    94→```
    95→
    96→## Performance
    97→
    98→- MarkdownUI re-renders when the content string changes. This is fine for normal files.
    99→  For very large files (10K+ lines), consider debouncing the file watcher reload.
   100→- Don't wrap the Markdown view in unnecessary containers. Keep the view hierarchy shallow.
   101→- Use `Equatable` on models to prevent unnecessary re-renders.
   102→

1→# Patterns & Conventions
     2→
     3→Solutions to problems you will encounter building Safo. Read before implementing.
     4→
     5→---
     6→
     7→## 0. MarkdownUI Custom Theme
     8→
     9→**Problem:** MarkdownUI ships with default themes but Safo needs fully custom typography,
    10→colors, and spacing for every markdown element.
    11→
    12→**Solution:** Create a custom `Theme` conforming to MarkdownUI's `Theme` protocol. Override
    13→every block and inline style.
    14→
    15→```swift
    16→import MarkdownUI
    17→
    18→struct SafoTheme: Theme {
    19→    // Use MarkdownUI's theme API to customize:
    20→    // - text styles (body, code, headings)
    21→    // - block styles (paragraph, blockquote, code block, table, list)
    22→    // - inline styles (strong, emphasis, strikethrough, code, link)
    23→    //
    24→    // Reference: https://github.com/gonzalezreal/swift-markdown-ui
    25→    // Look at Theme+DocC.swift and Theme+GitHub.swift in the repo for examples.
    26→}
    27→```
    28→
    29→**Gotcha:** MarkdownUI 2.x uses a declarative theme system with `BlockStyle` and
    30→`InlineStyle`. Do not try to use AttributedString directly. Work with the theme API.
    31→
    32→**Gotcha:** For heading sizes, MarkdownUI gives you the heading level (1-6) in the
    33→`BlockConfiguration`. Use a switch to apply different sizes per level.
    34→
    35→---
    36→
    37→## 1. Splash Integration with MarkdownUI
    38→
    39→**Problem:** MarkdownUI needs a code syntax highlighter. Splash is Swift-native but needs
    40→to be wired into MarkdownUI's code block rendering.
    41→
    42→**Solution:** MarkdownUI 2.x supports custom code syntax highlighters via the
    43→`.markdownCodeSyntaxHighlighter` modifier. Create a Splash-based highlighter.
    44→
    45→```swift
    46→import MarkdownUI
    47→import Splash
    48→
    49→struct SplashCodeHighlighter: CodeSyntaxHighlighter {
    50→    let theme: Splash.Theme
    51→
    52→    func highlightCode(_ code: String, language: String?) -> Text {
    53→        guard let language = language else {
    54→            return Text(code)
    55→        }
    56→        // Use Splash's SyntaxHighlighter to produce highlighted output
    57→        // Convert Splash's attributed output to SwiftUI Text
    58→    }
    59→}
    60→```
    61→
    62→**Gotcha:** Splash only highlights Swift natively. For other languages, it provides basic
    63→keyword highlighting. This is acceptable for v1. For more languages, consider switching to
    64→a different highlighter later.
    65→
    66→**Gotcha:** If Splash doesn't recognize the language, fall back to plain monospace text.
    67→Never crash on unknown languages.
    68→
    69→---
    70→
    71→## 2. Window Positioning on Launch
    72→
    73→**Problem:** Safo needs to open at 40% screen width, full height, positioned on the right
    74→side of the screen.
    75→
    76→**Solution:** Use `NSApplicationDelegate` to position the window after it appears.
    77→
    78→```swift
    79→class AppDelegate: NSObject, NSApplicationDelegate {
    80→    func applicationDidFinishLaunching(_ notification: Notification) {
    81→        positionWindow()
    82→    }
    83→
    84→    private func positionWindow() {
    85→        guard let screen = NSScreen.main else { return }
    86→        guard let window = NSApplication.shared.windows.first else { return }
    87→
    88→        let screenFrame = screen.visibleFrame
    89→        let width = screenFrame.width * Tokens.Layout.windowWidthRatio
    90→        let frame = NSRect(
    91→            x: screenFrame.maxX - width,
    92→            y: screenFrame.minY,
    93→            width: width,
    94→            height: screenFrame.height
    95→        )
    96→        window.setFrame(frame, display: true, animate: false)
    97→    }
    98→}
    99→```
   100→
   101→**Gotcha:** Use `screen.visibleFrame` not `screen.frame`. The visible frame excludes the
   102→menu bar and dock.
   103→
   104→**Gotcha:** The window may not exist yet when `applicationDidFinishLaunching` fires. Use
   105→`DispatchQueue.main.async` if needed, or observe `NSWindow.didBecomeKeyNotification`.
   106→
   107→---
   108→
   109→## 3. File Watching with DispatchSource
   110→
   111→**Problem:** Safo must detect when the currently viewed file changes on disk and reload.
   112→
   113→**Solution:** Use `DispatchSource.makeFileSystemObjectSource` to watch a specific file.
   114→
   115→```swift
   116→class FileWatcher {
   117→    private var source: DispatchSourceFileSystemObject?
   118→    private var fileDescriptor: Int32 = -1
   119→
   120→    init(url: URL, onChange: @escaping () -> Void) {
   121→        fileDescriptor = open(url.path, O_EVTONLY)
   122→        guard fileDescriptor >= 0 else { return }
   123→
   124→        source = DispatchSource.makeFileSystemObjectSource(
   125→            fileDescriptor: fileDescriptor,
   126→            eventMask: [.write, .rename, .delete],
   127→            queue: .main
   128→        )
   129→
   130→        source?.setEventHandler { [weak self] in
   131→            onChange()
   132→        }
   133→
   134→        source?.setCancelHandler { [weak self] in
   135→            guard let fd = self?.fileDescriptor, fd >= 0 else { return }
   136→            close(fd)
   137→        }
   138→
   139→        source?.resume()
   140→    }
   141→
   142→    deinit {
   143→        source?.cancel()
   144→    }
   145→}
   146→```
   147→
   148→**Gotcha:** Always close the file descriptor in the cancel handler, not in deinit directly.
   149→The cancel handler runs asynchronously.
   150→
   151→**Gotcha:** Some editors (like vim) write by creating a new file and renaming. This triggers
   152→`.rename` or `.delete` on the original descriptor. When you detect rename/delete, re-create
   153→the watcher for the same path.
   154→
   155→**Gotcha:** Debounce the onChange callback (100ms). Editors may write multiple times rapidly.
   156→
   157→---
   158→
   159→## 4. URL Scheme Handling
   160→
   161→**Problem:** The CLI needs to tell a running Safo instance to open a specific file.
   162→
   163→**Solution:** Register a custom URL scheme in Info.plist and handle it in SwiftUI.
   164→
   165→Info.plist:
   166→```xml
   167→<key>CFBundleURLTypes</key>
   168→<array>
   169→    <dict>
   170→        <key>CFBundleURLSchemes</key>
   171→        <array>
   172→            <string>safo</string>
   173→        </array>
   174→        <key>CFBundleURLName</key>
   175→        <string>com.significa.safo</string>
   176→    </dict>
   177→</array>
   178→```
   179→
   180→SwiftUI handler:
   181→```swift
   182→@main
   183→struct SafoApp: App {
   184→    var body: some Scene {
   185→        WindowGroup {
   186→            ContentView()
   187→                .onOpenURL { url in
   188→                    // url = safo://open?path=/absolute/path/to/file.md
   189→                    guard let components = URLComponents(url: url, resolvingAgainstBaseURL: false),
   190→                          let path = components.queryItems?.first(where: { $0.name == "path" })?.value
   191→                    else { return }
   192→                    viewModel.open(url: URL(fileURLWithPath: path))
   193→                }
   194→        }
   195→    }
   196→}
   197→```
   198→
   199→**Gotcha:** The path in the URL must be percent-encoded. The CLI must encode it.
   200→
   201→**Gotcha:** `onOpenURL` fires both when the app launches from a URL and when an already
   202→running app receives a URL. Handle both cases identically.
   203→
   204→---
   205→
   206→## 5. Single Instance Behavior
   207→
   208→**Problem:** Running `safo file.md` when Safo is already open should navigate to the new
   209→file in the existing window, not open a second window.
   210→
   211→**Solution:** Use `handlesExternalEvents` on the WindowGroup and configure the app to
   212→reuse the existing window.
   213→
   214→```swift
   215→@main
   216→struct SafoApp: App {
   217→    var body: some Scene {
   218→        WindowGroup {
   219→            ContentView()
   220→        }
   221→        .handlesExternalEvents(matching: Set(arrayLiteral: "*"))
   222→    }
   223→}
   224→```
   225→
   226→**Gotcha:** By default, `WindowGroup` creates a new window for each external event. The
   227→`handlesExternalEvents(matching:)` modifier with `"*"` routes all events to the existing
   228→window.
   229→
   230→**Gotcha:** Also set `NSSupportsAutomaticTermination` and `NSSupportsSuddenTermination` to
   231→`false` in Info.plist if you want predictable lifecycle behavior.
   232→
   233→---
   234→
   235→## 6. CLI Tool Implementation
   236→
   237→**Problem:** `safo file.md` must launch the app or send the file to a running instance.
   238→
   239→**Solution:** The CLI resolves the path to absolute, constructs a URL scheme, and opens it.
   240→
   241→```swift
   242→import Foundation
   243→
   244→@main
   245→struct SafoCLI {
   246→    static func main() {
   247→        guard CommandLine.arguments.count > 1 else {
   248→            print("Usage: safo <file.md>")
   249→            exit(1)
   250→        }
   251→
   252→        let rawPath = CommandLine.arguments[1]
   253→        let absolutePath: String
   254→
   255→        if rawPath.hasPrefix("/") {
   256→            absolutePath = rawPath
   257→        } else {
   258→            absolutePath = FileManager.default.currentDirectory + "/" + rawPath
   259→        }
   260→
   261→        // Verify file exists
   262→        guard FileManager.default.fileExists(atPath: absolutePath) else {
   263→            print("Error: file not found: \(absolutePath)")
   264→            exit(1)
   265→        }
   266→
   267→        // Construct URL scheme
   268→        let encoded = absolutePath.addingPercentEncoding(withAllowedCharacters: .urlQueryAllowed) ?? absolutePath
   269→        let url = "safo://open?path=\(encoded)"
   270→
   271→        // Open via macOS
   272→        let process = Process()
   273→        process.executableURL = URL(fileURLWithPath: "/usr/bin/open")
   274→        process.arguments = [url]
   275→        try? process.run()
   276→        process.waitUntilExit()
   277→    }
   278→}
   279→```
   280→
   281→**Gotcha:** Always resolve relative paths. The CLI's working directory is the user's
   282→terminal cwd, not the app's.
   283→
   284→**Gotcha:** Use `FileManager.default.currentDirectoryPath` (not `currentDirectory`).
   285→
   286→---
   287→
   288→## 7. Directory Scanning
   289→
   290→**Problem:** The sidebar needs all .md files in the current directory and subdirectories.
   291→
   292→**Solution:** Use `FileManager.enumerator` with a shallow depth or `contentsOfDirectory`
   293→recursively.
   294→
   295→```swift
   296→func scanMarkdownFiles(in directory: URL) -> [URL] {
   297→    let fm = FileManager.default
   298→    guard let enumerator = fm.enumerator(
   299→        at: directory,
   300→        includingPropertiesForKeys: [.isRegularFileKey],
   301→        options: [.skipsHiddenFiles]
   302→    ) else { return [] }
   303→
   304→    var files: [URL] = []
   305→    for case let fileURL as URL in enumerator {
   306→        if fileURL.pathExtension.lowercased() == "md" {
   307→            files.append(fileURL)
   308→        }
   309→    }
   310→    return files.sorted { $0.path < $1.path }
   311→}
   312→```
   313→
   314→**Gotcha:** Skip hidden files (`.skipsHiddenFiles`). Directories like `.git` contain
   315→markdown files you don't want to show.
   316→
   317→**Gotcha:** Sort alphabetically for predictable prev/next navigation.
   318→
   319→---
   320→
   321→## 8. Dark/Light Mode Theme Switching
   322→
   323→**Problem:** Safo must adapt all colors to the system appearance.
   324→
   325→**Solution:** Use `@Environment(\.colorScheme)` in views and make the Splash code theme
   326→dynamic.
   327→
   328→```swift
   329→struct MarkdownContentView: View {
   330→    @Environment(\.colorScheme) var colorScheme
   331→
   332→    var codeTheme: Splash.Theme {
   333→        colorScheme == .dark ? CodeTheme.dark : CodeTheme.light
   334→    }
   335→
   336→    var body: some View {
   337→        Markdown(content)
   338→            .markdownTheme(.safo)
   339→            .markdownCodeSyntaxHighlighter(
   340→                SplashCodeHighlighter(theme: codeTheme)
   341→            )
   342→    }
   343→}
   344→```
   345→
   346→**Gotcha:** MarkdownUI's built-in theme colors use SwiftUI semantic colors that adapt
   347→automatically. But Splash themes use fixed colors, so you need two Splash themes (dark
   348→and light) and switch based on colorScheme.
   349→
   350→---
   351→
   352→## 9. Copy Feedback
   353→
   354→**Problem:** After copying, the user needs brief visual confirmation.
   355→
   356→**Solution:** Temporarily change the copy button label from "Copy" to "Copied", then revert.
   357→
   358→```swift
   359→@State private var copied = false
   360→
   361→Button {
   362→    NSPasteboard.general.clearContents()
   363→    NSPasteboard.general.setString(content, forType: .string)
   364→    copied = true
   365→    DispatchQueue.main.asyncAfter(deadline: .now() + 1.5) {
   366→        copied = false
   367→    }
   368→} label: {
   369→    Text(copied ? "Copied" : "Copy")
   370→}
   371→```
   372→
   373→**Gotcha:** Use `NSPasteboard` (AppKit), not `UIPasteboard` (UIKit). This is macOS.
   374→

1→# Architecture
     2→
     3→## Overview
     4→
     5→Safo has two targets: a macOS SwiftUI app (`Safo`) and a CLI tool (`safo`). The CLI launches
     6→the app or communicates with a running instance. The app renders markdown files using MarkdownUI
     7→with a custom theme and watches the file system for changes.
     8→
     9→## Dependencies
    10→
    11→| Package | Purpose | Version |
    12→|---------|---------|---------|
    13→| [MarkdownUI](https://github.com/gonzalezreal/swift-markdown-ui) | GFM markdown rendering in SwiftUI | 2.4+ |
    14→| [Splash](https://github.com/JohnSundell/Splash) | Swift-native syntax highlighting | 0.16+ |
    15→
    16→No other dependencies. Keep it minimal.
    17→
    18→## Targets
    19→
    20→### Safo (macOS App)
    21→- SwiftUI app using `@main` App protocol
    22→- macOS 14+ (Sonoma)
    23→- Renders markdown, manages window, watches files
    24→
    25→### safo (CLI Tool)
    26→- Swift executable
    27→- Launches the app via `open` or sends file path to running instance via URL scheme
    28→- Resolves relative paths to absolute before sending
    29→
    30→## URL Scheme
    31→
    32→`safo://open?path=/absolute/path/to/file.md`
    33→
    34→The CLI tool constructs this URL and opens it. The app handles it via `onOpenURL`.
    35→
    36→## Data Flow
    37→
    38→```
    39→Terminal                    CLI (safo)                  App (Safo)
    40→───────                    ──────────                  ──────────
    41→safo file.md  ──────────>  Resolve path  ──────────>  onOpenURL / launch args
    42→                           Build URL                        │
    43→                           open URL                         ▼
    44→                                                    DocumentViewModel
    45→                                                    ├── loads file content
    46→                                                    ├── starts FileWatcher
    47→                                                    └── scans directory
    48→                                                            │
    49→                                                            ▼
    50→                                                    ContentView
    51→                                                    ├── MarkdownContentView (rendered MD)
    52→                                                    ├── SidebarView (file list)
    53→                                                    └── ToolbarView (controls)
    54→```
    55→
    56→## Models
    57→
    58→### MarkdownDocument
    59→```swift
    60→struct MarkdownDocument: Identifiable, Equatable {
    61→    let id: URL           // file URL (unique identifier)
    62→    let url: URL          // absolute file URL
    63→    var content: String   // raw markdown content
    64→    var lastModified: Date
    65→
    66→    var fileName: String  // derived: url.lastPathComponent
    67→    var relativePath: String // derived: relative to root directory
    68→}
    69→```
    70→
    71→### DirectoryListing
    72→```swift
    73→struct DirectoryListing {
    74→    let rootURL: URL                    // base directory
    75→    var files: [URL]                    // all .md files, sorted alphabetically
    76→    var currentIndex: Int               // index of current file in list
    77→
    78→    var currentFile: URL?               // files[currentIndex]

+# Claude Code Hook
+
+Auto-preview markdown files in Safo whenever Claude Code writes or edits a `.md` file.
+
+## Setup
+
+Add this hook to your Claude Code settings. You can configure it at project level (`.claude/settings.json`) or globally (`~/.claude/settings.json`).
+
+### Hook Configuration
+
+```json
+{
+  "hooks": {
+    "PostToolUse": [
+      {
+        "matcher": "Write",
+        "hooks": [
+          {
+            "type": "command",
+            "command": "case \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" in *.md|*.markdown) safo \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" ;; esac"
+          }
+        ]
+      },
+      {
+        "matcher": "Edit",
+        "hooks": [
+          {
+            "type": "command",
+            "command": "case \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" in *.md|*.markdown) safo \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" ;; esac"
+          }
+        ]
+      }
+    ]
+  }
+}
+```
+
+## Prerequisites
+
+The `safo` CLI binary must be in your PATH. After building:
+
+```sh
+swift build -c release
+cp .build/release/safo-cli /usr/local/bin/safo
+```
+
+## How It Works
+
+1. Claude Code writes or edits a file
+2. The PostToolUse hook fires after the tool completes
+3. The hook checks if the file has a `.md` or `.markdown` extension
+4. If it matches, it runs `safo <path>` which opens or navigates the Safo app to that file
+5. If Safo is already running, it reuses the existing window (single instance behavior)
+
+## Notes
+
+- The hook only triggers for markdown files. All other file types are ignored.
+- If the Safo app is not installed as a .app bundle with URL scheme registration, the CLI falls back to launching the binary directly via launch arguments.
+- The hook runs asynchronously and does not block Claude Code.

content.content:
1→# Claude Code Hook
     2→
     3→Auto-preview markdown files in Safo whenever Claude Code writes or edits a `.md` file.
     4→
     5→## Setup
     6→
     7→Add this hook to your Claude Code settings. You can configure it at project level (`.claude/settings.json`) or globally (`~/.claude/settings.json`).
     8→
     9→### Hook Configuration
    10→
    11→```json
    12→{
    13→  "hooks": {
    14→    "PostToolUse": [
    15→      {
    16→        "matcher": "Write",
    17→        "hooks": [
    18→          {
    19→            "type": "command",
    20→            "command": "case \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" in *.md|*.markdown) safo \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" ;; esac"
    21→          }
    22→        ]
    23→      },
    24→      {
    25→        "matcher": "Edit",
    26→        "hooks": [
    27→          {
    28→            "type": "command",
    29→            "command": "case \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" in *.md|*.markdown) safo \"$CLAUDE_FILE_PATH\" ;; esac"
    30→          }
    31→        ]
    32→      }
    33→    ]
    34→  }
    35→}
    36→```
    37→
    38→## Prerequisites
    39→
    40→The `safo` CLI binary must be in your PATH. After building:
    41→
    42→```sh
    43→swift build -c release
    44→cp .build/release/safo-cli /usr/local/bin/safo
    45→```
    46→
    47→## How It Works
    48→
    49→1. Claude Code writes or edits a file
    50→2. The PostToolUse hook fires after the tool completes
    51→3. The hook checks if the file has a `.md` or `.markdown` extension
    52→4. If it matches, it runs `safo <path>` which opens or navigates the Safo app to that file
    53→5. If Safo is already running, it reuses the existing window (single instance behavior)
    54→
    55→## Notes
    56→
    57→- The hook only triggers for markdown files. All other file types are ignored.
    58→- If the Safo app is not installed as a .app bundle with URL scheme registration, the CLI falls back to launching the binary directly via launch arguments.
    59→- The hook runs asynchronously and does not block Claude Code.
    60→

The app is built with SPM (`swift build`), which produces executables but not a .app bundle. For the URL scheme (`safo://`) to work, the app needs to be registered with macOS Launch Services, which requires a .app bundle with the Info.plist embedded.

So realistically, the user has two paths forward: either create a .app bundle to enable the URL scheme, or just invoke the binary directly with file paths and install the CLI tool in PATH for convenience.

The user is asking if this is the most accessible approach and what other non-App Store Mac apps typically do. Let me think about this honestly.

For non-App Store Mac apps, the common distribution patterns are:

1. **DMG with drag-to-Applications** - This is the most common and recognizable pattern for Mac users. You open the DMG, drag the app to Applications. Examples: VS Code, Firefox, Figma, Sketch, etc. This is what users expect.

2. **Homebrew Cask** - Very common for developer tools. `brew install --cask app-name`. Examples: iTerm2, Raycast, etc. But requires maintaining a cask formula and the app still needs to be a .app bundle distributed somewhere.


3. **Homebrew formula** - For CLI tools. `brew install tool-name`. Examples: gh, ripgrep, etc.

4. **GitHub Release with zip** - Common for smaller/niche tools. Download zip, extract, move to Applications manually.

5. **PKG installer** - Less common, more enterprise-y.

For Safo specifically, since it's a small team tool with both a GUI app and CLI component used by technical people, the DMG pattern is still the most accessible for the Mac app itself, though for a developer tool I could also consider Homebrew Cask as a complementary distribution method.

Actually, thinking about what's truly most accessible for their specific situation—a small internal team of developers and designers—I'm realizing the answer depends on whether we're optimizing for universal recognition or practical developer experience. A Homebrew tap would be the cleanest for developers, but setting up a separate repo and maintaining formulas might be overkill for an internal tool. Based on the search results, here's how Homebrew tap structure and repositories work:

## What is a Homebrew Tap?

A tap is Homebrew-speak for a Git repository containing additional formulae. Taps are third-party repositories of formulas, allowing anyone to create their own custom repository alongside Homebrew's main repository (homebrew-core).

## Repository Structure and Naming

On GitHub, your repository must be named homebrew-something in order to use the one-argument form of brew tap, with the prefix 'homebrew-' being mandatory. However, when you use brew tap on the command line, you can leave out the 'homebrew-' prefix, so brew tap username/foobar can be used as a shortcut for brew tap username/homebrew-foobar.

Homebrew only needs the Formula directory, created at Formula/<your-app>.rb. Additionally, cask files can be placed in a Casks directory at the top level of your tap.

## How It Works

Running brew tap <user>/<repo> makes a clone of the repository at https://github.com/<user>/homebrew-<repo> into $(brew --repository)/Library/Taps. After that, brew will be able to work with those formulae as if they were in Homebrew's homebrew/core canonical repository, allowing installation and uninstallation with brew [un]install, with formulae automatically updated when you run brew update.

A tap is just a Git repository, so modifications are made by committing and pushing changes, and once installed, Homebrew will update it each time a user runs brew update.
